'''Hubert van Es''' (6 July 1941 â 15 May 2009) was a Dutch [[photographer]] and [[photojournalist]] who took the well-known photo on 29 April 1975, which shows [[South Vietnamese]] civilians scrambling to board a [[CIA]] [[Air America (airline)|Air America]] [[helicopter]] during the U.S. evacuation of Saigon. The picture was taken a day before the [[Fall of Saigon]].
Born in [[Hilversum]], [[Netherlands]], Van Es was variously known in his working life as "Hu", the anglicized "Hugh" and the nickname "Vanes," to rhyme with "planes".
On 15 May 2009, Van Es died in [[Queen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong|Queen Mary Hospital]], [[Hong Kong]], at the age of 67 from a [[haemorrhagic stroke]]. He had lived in Hong Kong since the end of the [[Vietnam War]].
==Career in Vietnam==
In 1975 Hubert Van Es was working in Saigon for [[United Press International]]. He remained in the city for as long as possible before its occupation by [[North Vietnamese]] troops. On 29 April 1975 he had taken pictures of Saigonese burning documents that could associate them with the [[United States]] as well as a picture of a [[Marine (military)|Marine]] confronting a Vietnamese mother and her little boy. Later that day he took his famous picture:
{{Cquote2|Around 2:30 in the afternoon, while I was working in the darkroom, I suddenly heard Bert Okuley shout, "Van Es, get out here, there's a chopper on that roof!" I grabbed my [[camera]] and the longest lens left in the office - it was only 300 millimeters, but it would have to do - and dashed to the balcony. He described the event as follows:
"Looking at the Pittman Apartments, I could see 20 or 30 people on the roof, climbing the ladder to an Air America Huey helicopter. At the top of the ladder stood an American in civilian clothes, pulling people up and shoving them inside. Of course, there was no possibility that all the people on the roof could get into the helicopter, and it took off with 12 or 14 on board. (The recommended maximum for that model was eight.) Those left on the roof waited for hours, hoping for more helicopters to arrive. To no avail. The enemy was closing in. I remember looking up to the sky and giving a short prayer. After shooting about 10 frames, I went back to the darkroom to process the film and get a print ready for the regular 5 p.m. transmission to [[Tokyo]] from Saigon's telegraph office."<ref name="mishalov">{{cite web |date=April 29, 2005| url = http://www.mishalov.com/Vietnam_finalescape.html| title = Thirty Years at 300 Millimeters| publisher = [[New York Times]]| accessdate = 2007-07-24 | last=HUBERT VAN ES }}</ref>}}
When North Vietnamese troops arrived, Van Es wore a [[camouflage]] hat bearing a small plastic [[Dutch flag]] printed with the Vietnamese words ''Bao Chi Ha Lan'' ("Dutch Press").
[[File:Saigon-hubert-van-es.jpg|thumb|Evacuation of [[CIA]] station personnel by [[Air America (airline)|Air America]] on April 29, 1975. <sub>Photo: Hubert van Es / UPI</sub>]] The building in the photo, which has been incorrectly identified as the [[US Embassy, Saigon]] since the 1970s, was not labeled as such by Van Es<ref>{{cite news |date=April 23, 2000| url =http://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/23/weekinreview/the-world-getting-it-wrong-in-a-photo.html?pagewanted=1| title = Getting it wrong in a photo| publisher = [[New York Times]] | first1=Fox | last1=Butterfield | first2=Kari | last2=Haskell | accessdate=4 May 2010}}</ref>. He has stated that he wrote, for the caption of his photograph, that the helicopter was taking evacuees off the roof of a CIA building in downtown Saigon ([[22 Gia Long Street]]).<ref name="mishalov"/> The current address is 22 LÃ½ Tá»± Trá»ng Street, and visitors are not allowed access to the roof.
==Later career== Van Es covered the [[Insurgency in the Philippines]] in the [[Philippines]] and the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]]. He attempted to return to [[Vietnam]] but was not able to do so until 1990. Upon his return to Vietnam, while visiting the countryside, he was quoted as remarking: "It [Vietnam] hasn't really changed since I was last here; but our photos changed the views of those who were lucky enough not to witness this terrible war."
